commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Morel support?  (4)
2. Sticky treats, in more ways than one?  (9)
3. Harsh sentences?  (6)(8)
4. Vineyard eponym  (6)
5. It's a little shady  (6)(4)


STEM
POPSICLES
TONGUE TWISTERS
MARTHA
BONSAI TREE


Note: #4 and #5 come from a puzzle that I co-constructed, but these clues were not made by me.

63A as clued is GEARS in a crossword, 
but will our auto enthusiasts deem 
P and N to be GEARS in real life?




(Home, James.)
Hear is some theme music for today's puzzle: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FGVGFfj7POA

Something of a nit-pick for me, but 5A (CBC) feels like it's poorly described. The CBC is national in scope, and while it's true that their HQ is in Ottawa, they have facilities all over Canada. "Ontario-based" feels inapposite.

When Hermey fixes the clock at midnight, it's an elf on the twelve.

(Probably should workshop these.)

Boy, am I always glad when another Monday comes along.

(I should stress, this is for crossword reasons only) üòÜ

Loved this puzzle! It was one of those that, even though it's only 4 p.m. here, makes me wish it went on and on until after midnight. Bonus points for the musical score. :-) Mr. Eric Clapton with "After Midnight" https://youtu.be/MkrA-gSG-vE?feature=shared Thank you, Mr. Cook, for a really great puzzle ‚Äì and the ear worm. Congratulations on this applause-worthy debut!
Ah, my old friend Stelmo. Only when he showed up did I realize that needed Sallie and not Fannie.

10D ‚ÄúLike yesterday‚Äù

EXPRESS CHECKOUT 

Congratulations, Glenn, on a fine debut.
Not a Monday level puzzle.

The universe is trying to tell me something.
This is, by total coincidence, I believe the first time I have ever done a ‚Äúnext-day‚Äôs‚Äù puzzle before midnight.

(I thought you don‚Äôt tell secrets on the farm, cuz corns talk.)

Fun debut!  
Some entries in the ‚Äútake the theme and mess with it‚Äù (a genre I enjoy):

MIDNIGHT SNACK MIX: whatever you can find that has no crinkly wrapper to give you away.

MIDNIGHT MASS TRANSIT: in some rural areas, sorry, there isn‚Äôt any.  

MIDNIGHT COWBOY BOOTS : ‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm walkin‚Äô here!‚Äù

MIDNIGHT OIL PAINT: for insomniacs who don‚Äôt do the crosswords.

Detroiters remember CBC as our fourth broadcast network in the pre-cable days.  I miss curling and CBC international news, which gave an objective view of the Viet Nam war, including a war protest at University of Windsor attended by officials from North Viet Nam. 
Wayne and Shuster (sp.?) were great comics.  Public schools in  Detroit used to start the class week with The Star Spangled Banner and O, Canada!  We learned and sang both anthems. During my undergraduate years at Trinity College, CT I would stay up late to listen to CKLW AM, Windsor to cure homesickness. Trinity offered an elective to history majors, History of Canada. My college fraternity, Delta Kappa Epsilon, has chapters at McGill and UBC.  When we had curbside boxes downtown for selling newspapers, we had boxes for the Windsor Star and the Toronto Globe and Mail.  On June 6, Detroit students are expected to know of the heroic sacrifices of Canadian troops at Gold, Sword and Juno beaches.

Neither P nor N are gears. Neutral is specifically the disengagement of the gears. In other words, it‚Äôs  ‚Äútaking it out of‚Äù gear. 

And park is the physical blocking of the gears from turning.
What a blast having so many heavy hitters before midnight!

Seeing the 9D clue reminded me of a recent concert I saw at Walt Disney Concert Hall by the San Francisco-based choral group Chanticleer. (They've made an annual LA appearance during the holiday season for several decades now.) One of the numbers always included on the program is "Ave Maria." Here's a performance of the piece (recorded in a different venue a few years ago): - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L7C-VXZVSTw It's a sublime performance sung in a beautiful arrangement.

Loved the puzzle ‚Äî smooth and perfect for a Monday!

But what kind of monster puts KALE in
a Caesar salad?

a rare, for me, night-before puzzle solve. And a fun one.

I'm not gonna make it 'til midnight, tho.

Sam, the puzzles seem to like terms from tennis and crew, too.

Yow on YAO. I'd wanted Mao, of course.

Fun puzzle!

I stumbled across @fter midnight when I added an extra 60 minutes to the recording of the Steven Colbert show on CBS.  (I added extra time to ensure I captured all of his show after missing some of it with some event - probably football or conventions or debates - I forget).  It's a fun comedy game show.

Thanks to the constructor!

Congratulations on a fun debut, Mr. Cook!

I‚Äôm glad you found a way to work in ‚ÄúMidnight Cowboy.‚Äù It‚Äôs got some unforgettable scenes in it.

A very clever and fun debut from Glenn Cook. Glad to see so many of my favorite commenters weighing in with love for this one despite the inevitable posts regarding clue issues and day-of-week remarks. (Yawn.)

At least nobody has continued the drama over Art Heist Sunday. (Yet.) It feels like years from now if I enter the forum someone will still be throwing shade at that puzzle (which I loved).

One of the things I enjoy nabout this community is that every day is fresh. The puzzle is always the star, but the content and scope of comments varies in a way that creates a different mood. I feel I am among friends. Sam, Deb, and Caitlin definitely factor in for those who read the columns. (If you don‚Äôt, you should.)

So far today‚Äôs mood is quite positive and fun. As it should be. Happy holidays to all! And to all a good (mid)night!

I‚Äôm out of sync with the puzzles over the last few days as we celebrated Christmas on Saturday, it being the only time all the family could be together. I‚Äôm now in this weird but pleasant post Christmas chill mode. Dec 25th is going to be a bit of a shock.

I‚Äôll catch up with the missed puzzles anon, but today‚Äôs debut was a delight. I admit it took a while to grasp the theme, even though the fill was smooth. It felt Mondayish with a little bite; HALFSIES and ORONO were new to me.

Enjoy the final, mad rush up to Christmas everyone. I‚Äôm going to be all smug and that. Turkey eaten, most presents open, house decorated to within an inch of its life. We‚Äôre having roast beef for Christmas lunch; the last lovely joint from Erin, last year‚Äôs cow. (With apologies to the vegetarians out there; she had a splendid life eating luscious grass, with the sun warming her back)

Now I‚Äôm even finding that I need help for a Monday puzzle, and only a couple of others felt the same.  

Never mind, it was a fun theme.  I like lots of theme fills and enjoyed this one, so looking forward to more from Glenn.

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Glenn. Alternate clue for 50D: [What the governor of Maryland mistook for dozens of large drones, proving he had never looked up in the sky before] ... and from J.J. Cale: https://youtu.be/2x0JK8vhmcc?si=BJEUmC3kF4duB9Rz

Fun puzzle and a clever theme. Just some nice 'aha' moments when things dawned on me. Glad to see our new constructor - looking forward to more from Mr. Cook. 

Stumbled across a really unusual puzzle today. I'll put that in a reply. 

...
A very enjoyable puzzle, although I shudder at the thought of putting kale in a Caesar salad - just NO!

Nice Monday puzzle!

7D. My denouement, and my pick for Sam's column headline.
If I could have come up with the "X" at the end of 17A maybe things would have been different.

Happy Hoppy Holidays! Have an IPA on me this week!

Glad to see others are also affronted by the idea of putting kale in a Caesar salad üòÖ 
Nice puzzle, congrats on the debut

Oh... one more late puzzle find. A Wednesday from January 16, 2019 by Bruce Haight. Just thought this one was kind of cute. Theme clues and answers: 

"___, do these jeans make me look fat?" 
BUTTWEIGHT

"___! The flight attendant just swatted a bug!" 
AISLEBEE

"___, would you like to purchase some religious music?"
BUYCHANTS

"___ and those crazy sheep costumes!"
EWEGUISE

"___! Petr, I'm begging you again to let me get this!"
CZECHPLEAS

I'm done. 

...

A tale about KALE.  

For most of my life it was a nonentity; it‚Äôs not that I avoided it, but rather, I never considered it.  No attraction for me at all. Then I started hearing about it as a nutritional powerhouse, and started eating it every now and then.  It was okay tasting, so, for my own good, I soldiered through it.  Then, suddenly, I grew to really like it, especially if cooked and dressed with olive oil and maybe a touch of salt.  And now I‚Äôve become one of those people that actually seeks it out, drools at the thought of it.  Give. Me. Kale.

End of a tale about KALE.

A terrific and very smooth debut but must confess the reveal took a second or two to register.  Well done and thanks. 

STRANDS THREAD, Please no spoilers until after the view all replies button:

Strands #295
‚ÄúPass the eggnog‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµ

Another seasonal offering with an interesting twist.   At 5, lowest word count possible?
"BLASTOFF"?  Not from any launch countdown I've ever heard.  It's "LIFTOFF."

A nice light theme and a quick Monday before I start the Christmas preparations.

I must also join the chorus of those who consider KALE to be an abomination and utterly unacceptable ingredient in the classic Caesar salad.  KALE has its place in many dishes, but when it becomes the green of choice in a salad with egg yolk, Worcestershire sauce, Parmesan cheese, garlic, and anchovy, it is no longer a Caesar salad!
Under 10 minutes but felt trickier than a Monday during the acrosses. HALFSIES, CAROMS, and SECEDE were fun!

As a Canadian I feel the need to point out that CBC/Radio Canada is not solely Ontario based, it is a crown corporation with stations all over the country that serves the Canadian public - might be a bit misleading as a clue!

Hmm.  I did post a comment about this puzzle, singing its praises, but it didn't show up.  I tried again, still with no result.  I can't see anything in the comment that would disqualify it.  So, hopefully, it will show up later.  Anyway, Glenn, I had a great time with your puzzle, and congratulations on your debut!

AFTER MIDNIGHT is a great Eric Clapton tune.

And, CYMBOL is not spelled with an i.

Please note that while in ORONO one can listen to CBC.

Nice one Glenn

As another Canadian agree that CBC is the Canadian Broadcasting Com[any..  the Ontario based one would be TVO something like PBS in content!! As far as Orono is concerned....Sam  you need to drive to PEI this summer to see Anne of Green Gables! !   Once you pass Bangor on i95 you will see the sign for for Orono... then you are only about 5 hours from the Confederation bridge to PEI...At 8 miles in length it is the longest bridge in the world to span water that ices over!!   Merry Christmas..Jim Mcdougalll
Re: CBC. Yeah, it‚Äôs not a good clue. Like other Canadians here, I read that and thought, ‚Äúthat isn‚Äôt right.‚Äù

Nice start Mr. Cook. Please keep them coming. 
As usual, I failed to note the theme till Ms. Corbin pointed it out.

Excellent debut puzzle! Congrats to our constructor. Almost the perfect Monday puzzle, with a fine theme and good fill. Having ORONO and ORION running parallel to one another is a nice visual bonus.

Never heard of Taylor Tomlinson or the CBS program. I'd have referenced Eric Clapton's hit cover in the revealer instead. But that's just me.

Sorry Mr. Puzzle creator, but only in Google AI's broken mind is Cosin the opposite of Sin. You meant to put Arcsin or write a different clue entirely. Stop confusing folks about math, we have teachers for that! Other than that blatant wrong answer and the CBC snafu you did alright.

CBS Late Show?  For us, something startiing at 7 p.m.  
Come to think of it, don't actually watch that channel.  Oh, well.

MOUSSE, TORTES, SNACK MIX--pretty low on nutrition, eh?

STOLID before STEADY.
And, once again, ELAN clued in an odd way.  Savoir faire, style, brio, enthusiasm -- those are more accurate IMHO.   

When a small group of us Band  members formed a combo for the annual musical staged at our HS, the drummer brought his trap set. ...and one foot pedal came off mid-way through a piece.  Yikes.  Pretty sure HI-HAT rather than CYMBAL was the terminology--and nobody called it his "drum kit."  

Whatever became of YAO Ming?
Nice puzzle, Glenn Cook!  Enjoyed it, except for being reminded of MIDNIGHT COWBOY.
This is the only Monday puzzle ever where I didn't understand the answer to a clue until after getting the "completion jingle" (P, R, N, D, or L... very nice!).

During my mom's campus tour of ORONO, my grandfather famously exclaimed, "Well, we won't have to worry about your finding a husband here, they're all farmers and lumberjacks!" (He had just seen a guy in a plaid jacket, carrying a double-bit ax through the student union.) Lucky thing my dad was an engineer.
Excellent Monday with a nice theme!  My only complaint is cluing 34A with anything other than ‚ÄúClassic Thelonious Monk tune.‚Äù

And yet they still haven't canonized Kermit! Explain that.

I never would've guessed the theme without the revealer. And on a Monday? Good job, Mr. Cook!



It's not easy being green.

Mmm, this puzzle was full of treats! MOUSSE-topped TORTES sound perfectly appropriate at this time of year. (And indeed the one is over the other in the grid!) Even AFTER MIDNIGHT had me thinking of After Eight mints... December is all about the peppermint for me. CYMBAL was an easy gimme after avidly listening to this fascinating piece on-AIR RECENTly: https://www.npr.org/2024/12/14/nx-s1-5220127/zildjian-brand-cymbals-are-everywhere-but-how-theyre-made-is-a-400-year-secret But really I'm just here to correct the glaring gap in mentions of the iconic Aussie band MIDNIGHT OIL! Sam talked about "burning the midnight oil", so perhaps I should link to one of their most famous tracks, Beds Are Burning. Instead here is my favorite: https://youtu.be/Ofrqm6-LCqs?si=l-Vu-Hq1n1BiOuyn Thanks, Glen Cook! Looking forward to more: seconds, please! :)
Congratulations, Glenn!  A perfect Monday puzzle.  Do more!

I‚Äôm surprised to be the first person to mention it, (or maybe they‚Äôre all in emu jail) but COXES are not necessarily captains of rowing crews. They might be default captains if there isn‚Äôt another one appointed but it‚Äôs not a given. I suppose they captain the boat in that they are responsible for steering it in the correct direction, but it‚Äôs quite normal for a crew to have a captain and a coxswain. 

(I guess this is a long way to say this clue tripped me up for quite a while!)
I solved this in a few seconds more than my average for a Monday. I didn't get the theme, though, until I read Sam's column. Pleasant enough, though. Nice debut, Glenn!
No snoozing on this Monday puzzle. You cooked up a classic beginner's crossword, Glenn. Bravo!

For the last week or so, I‚Äôve started doing the Crossword Puzzle after finishing Wordle, Spelling Bee, The Mini Crossword, Letter Box, Tiles, and Strands. Today I actually finished it in less than an hour! I know it‚Äôs probably not a big deal to others who complete it a lot faster, but I‚Äôve completed The Mini in less than a minute at times. I LOVE when there is a theme/code in the puzzle and I really enjoyed it too! Thanks again and Happy Christmas!! Namaste.
KALE in a Caesar salad?

Unless I don't know something specific about Canadian English,  I'm astounded at how many Canadians have written in to comment that by saying that a company's headquarters is in a specific province (or, by extension, a state in the US), you mean that company must be a business local to just that province.

Every company, no matter how large, has a headquarters somewhere, and almost always, has one main headquarters, even if they have regional headquarters.

As was pointed out earlier, Walmart's HQ is in Arkansas.

Ford's and GM's are in Michigan. Tesla's is in Texas.

IBM's self-described world headquarters is in New York.

Tim Hortons' is in Ontario.  As is Rogers Communications.  As is TD Bank.  And oddly enough, Bank of Montreal and Bank of Nova Scotia as well.

Canada Post, of course, is headquartered in Ontario, too.  That's certainly a nationwide business.

All of the above businesses are national and international operations.  Every one of them has a headquarters.  Every headquarters is in a certain province or state.

Unless "headquarters" means something drastically different in Canada than it does in the US, there's nothing to complain about with the clue.  (And even then so, it's an American puzzle.)

Clearly it's a controversial recommendation, but for anyone in the Kansas City area, I recommend this offering from Red Door (I still miss their jalape√±o fried chicken as well):

HAIL CAESAR
Hearts of romaine, kale, avocado, crispy capers, parmesan, herbed croutons, creamy anchovy dressing
Who the heck puts kale in a Caesar salad???

If I respond directly to Lewis's paean to KALE this morning, it will be buried under at least 7 other Replies, never to be seen again -- in what passes for a scrolling "system"  at the NYTXW.  So it's time for a reprise of my erstwhile KALE ditty:

To be sung to the tune of "I Hate Men" by Cole Porter

Oh, I hate KALE!
And anyone who cooks with it will fail!
You put it in a salad and the salad you diminish.
You put it in a casserole -- your family won't finish.
And then you know what others know: You should have cooked with spinash!
Oh, I hate KALE!
Absolutely HATE clues like 54D... üôÑ
A lot of trivia in this one, not a huge fan

A late puzzle find, appropriate for this time of year, and I don't recall seeing one quite like this before. Anyway - a Sunday from December 22, 1996 by Frances Hansen with the title: "Taking off for the holidays." As far as I can tell that was the only hint to the trick in this one. Four 21 letter theme answers. Note that the last answer is exactly as it appears. SOFARIHAVENTMADEITFIT IMPOSITIVEITCANBEDONE AHNOWIVEGOTITTHISISIT MERRYCHRISTMASEVERYON Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/22/1996&g=106&d=A .....

Oof. This felt more like a Tuesday or a Wednesday to me. Real Natick with the ARREARS/STELMO/ORONO corner. My slowest time in awhile.

Emus don't eat

A few too many proper nouns for my liking, like Former NBA Star, College loan provider, University of Maine town, many of those being crossed with some wild trivia.

But I suppose my little nitpick is for 23Down, CGI is not _Special_ Effects, CGI is _Visual_ Effects. _Special_ Effects are practical, like pyrotechnics and animatronics. _Visual_ Effects are created digitally.
Great theme and very straightforward Monday-type cluing. Except for 5A (CBC), which I only got through the crosses, and I'll pass on the caesar salad with 14A.
great debut, glenn, and i really appreciate your constructor notes. next time, i would LOVE to see a curling-themed puzzle! ü•åüôÉ

Fun and easy puzzle for a Monday, just as it should be. But, no, kale is not ever in a Caesar salad. Never. No more than you would put Brussels sprouts in a Caesar salad. You get a pass, Glenn, as this is your first NYT crossword. 

P.S. Caesar Cardini invented the Caesar salad in Tijuana, Mexico, in 1924. He didn't use kale.
As a female officer in the military- not a fan of clue 64 across.
Taylor Tomlinson is my favorite comedian and it was great to see her getting a shout-out in the crossword!

I love Mondays because while I have to think deeply about a few clues, it is never enough for a lookup, and I completed it in under 16 minutes! Your tricky clue of Orono was an easy one for me, as we head the US Junior racewalking camps there in the summer in the 90s. It's a beautiful area!
I agree with others on the Kale. It is not a Caesar salad with that in it, so a more apt description would be in order here.
Here in Portland all of my favorite Caesar salads have kale in them. But then again I'm vegan so I'm frequenting a lot of kale positive restaurants

Kale, a GMO cabbage, does not belong in Caesar Salad.  It's made with romaine.
Otherwise, good Monday puzzle.

@Lewis 

Lewis, today I watched CBS Sunday Morning and they had a piece on Ashville regarding the annual gingerbread competition.  The resilience and comraderie and determination of your "neighbors" are a testament to what people can achieve with open minds, loving hearts and helping hands.  Best wishes to you and the folks of Ashville.

@Min -- Thank you so much for those good wishes.  Our neighborhood became much closer, people helping people, through the weeks and months after Helene.  The city has mostly returned to normal, but the areas near the rivers were decimated, and things are still nightmarish there. 

Regarding the gingerbread competition, it's truly amazing the houses -- all the detail that goes into them -- that people make.

@Barry Ancona one can probably argue that Park is a gear since basically it‚Äôs a pin which pops into a gear looking wheel to stop the wheels from moving.

As for Neutral‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs the null set‚Ä¶so hard to find a way that it‚Äôs actually a gear.  Perhaps if the phrase is ‚Äúgear position‚Äù which could encapsulate all of the positions in an automatic transmission.

@Barry Ancona 

Close enough for a crossword. This isn‚Äôt the SAE.
@Steve Self-Addressed Envelope? ü§î

"Close enough for a crossword."

Steve,
Yes, I agree. 
I did write:
"63A as clued is GEARS in a crossword..."

@Sebastian 
SAE = Society of Atomotive Engineers

@Barry Ancona similar quibble with 7D ‚ÄúRowing crew captains, informally‚Äù answer COXES. I get why this would be acceptable in a crossword for the general population, but no rower would say the coxswain is the captain of the team automatically. If the crew team has a captain, they may have elected the cox as captain, but it‚Äôs not a title for them by default. COXES steer the boat and get the voice box when the team is on the water, but they are not automatically the captain of a crew team. Similar to how any other team elects their captain, who may be a leader from any position.
@Barry Ancona Wednesday Witch!
N.B. The homophone was ringing, so I answered it.

@Andrew Reid 

Doesn‚Äôt ‚ÄúOttawa-based‚Äù literally mean ‚Äúheadquartered in Ottawa‚Äù?

Andrew Reid,

The clue did strike me as a bit odd, I think because it had me imagining (mostly American) people (not) thinking ‚ÄúOh, wait, which of the many Canadian television networks I know is based in Ontario, and which are based elsewhere in Canada?‚Äù Maybe that‚Äôs just me. Otherwise, no disputing the  CBC is based in Ontario. Maybe saying based in Canada would be too easy for a Monday - more like a themeless Sunday clue?

@Justin 

But unlike Elmo, STELMO is blue, like the Mini's SMURF.
Too easy or too hard?

@Jules Lee 

Based on solver input, the statistics site xwstats.com calls it Average (for a Monday), with the medial solver 6% faster than average, well within the range of an "Average" puzzle.

So what‚Äôs harder than a Monday level? Well, a Tuesday level, for starters. What‚Äôs easier than a Monday level? That‚Äôs a good question. Same for what‚Äôs harder than a Saturday level. Kinda reminds me of the scene from Spinal Tap where Nigel shows how their amp can go beyond the highest level ‚Ä¶ not only to 10, but to 11 https://youtu.be/4xgx4k83zzc?si=olhAIVYRYU51M8I5
@Andrzej   I'm not a basketball fan either, but I knew Yao Ming because of one thing: his exceptional height:  7'6".

@Andrzej 

Today's theme is a lot like Connections, in that you have four words, SNACK, MASS, COWBOY and OIL, and the revealer is the word that connects them all.  Without that word, the four words are completely unrelated.

MIDNIGHT OIL is an idiom that refers to working late; the full phrase is to burn the MIDNIGHT OIL.

MIDNIGHT SNACK is self-explanatory; I assume that Poles occasionally get hungry late at night, just as Americans sometimes do.

MIDNIGHT COWBOY was a 1969 film starring a young Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman.  It was the first and only X-rated movie to ever win an Academy Award; that was before X-rated referred strictly to pornography (this type of film is now classified as NC-17 [no children under 17]).  The reason for the rating was the subject matter; Voight played a male prostitute who was befriended by a con artist (Hoffman).  

I'm sure they have MIDNIGHT MASS in Poland, although I'm aware you won't be attending (neither will I).

One final note:  YAO Ming doesn't seem to me to be parochially American; he was born in China and achieved international fame as perhaps the most famous Chinese basketball player in history.  But maybe he's not a big deal in Poland.

Anyway, the xwstats.com statistics are an average.  They say 33% of solvers solved more slowly than average.  It depends on what you know.

@Steve L Thank you :) It feels great that you so often take the time to explain all this stuff to me. I'm just sorry I can never remember antyhing about baseball - I do remember RBI thanks to you though, even if I can no longer recall any details about it. Midnight oil I knew myself - it was the first themed answer that jumped out at me when crosses revealed the revealer. I had heard of Midnight Cowboy but knew nothing about it except the title: your post intrigued me to the extent that I may break my rule about not watching movies. Midnight mass is a huge thing at midnight on Christmas Eve. It is called pasterka. My physio goes to one in one of Warsaw's most beautiful churches (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Church_of_the_Holiest_Saviour) and she says it is magical (if all Polish Catholics were as wonderful as she is - wise, strong, loving, compassionate - this country would be the best place in the world). But yeah, I never go as I don't have a religious bone in my body. My wife knows about Yao Ming, but she used to watch basketball in the 1990s and 2000s. He may well be a big deal in Poland - but I'm as a-typical for a Pole as it gets (leftist, atheist, childless, happy to pay taxes, worried about climate change, not interested in football, mock-documentaries and clickbait news... and it goes on). It's just that I personally have zero interest in his sport.
@Steve L obscure cultural references made it too hard.

@Andrzej

 1. Had almost exactly the same experience.

@Andrzej 
I struggled there as well.

@Andrzej same here! Been living in the US for several years and I still needed to lookup COXES to solve that corner (had CBs and YA? and so was stumped at that part of the cross). Didn‚Äôt get the theme until the very end, though tbf the theme wasn‚Äôt needed to solve the themed entries. Very smooth and enjoyable apart from that!
@jrrg1 Hockey Night in Canada. Ward Cornell.

K. H.,

We missed you in the thread!

@K. H. 

They are still letters on a gearbox.
@RichardZ thank you for that link‚Äîthat is my favorite arrangement and indeed a beautiful performance!

@Adam 

Maybe Gaius Cassius Longinus? the instigator of the plot to murder Caesar? Consider Shakespeare's line, "Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look...."

@Dutchiris

Or was it CLEO, thinking back to her (Caesar) salad days‚Ä¶when she was green in judgment?

@Adam 

Maybe we should be glad it was not sauerkraut or half a pound of nails...
@Andrzej or Kimchi.

@Adam OK, OK, I know some people have negative feelings about kale, from when it used to be used only as a garnish atop the ice on a salad bar (remember those?). But it can be really yummy in a Caesar salad. I was surprised too! In my middle age, I am committed to Trying New Things - and Kale Caesar Salad is one of those that I wasn't sorry to have tried. YMMV.

@JR I have been known to order, and enjoy, a Chicken Caesar Salad. But that doesn't mean that 'Protein sometime found in a Caesar Salad' is a valid clue for CHICKEN.
In other words, if you add kale it's no longer a Caesar salad! 

If I ordered a Caesar salad and they brought me something with kale in it, I'd send it back, because it's not what I ordered! (and because kale ruins things)

(BTW - I only filled in KALE because it's the 4-letter leafy answer that regularly show up in crosswords).

@Andrzej 
Kieflies are a traditional holiday pastry here in north central Indiana.  Possibly Hungarian rather than Polish, because immigrants from both settled here, but I‚Äôm wondering if they sound familiar to your own traditions? Flaky dough, walnut filling, rolled in powdered sugar?

@retired, with cats 

That does not sound familiar - neither flaky dough nor walnuts feature prominently in Polish cuisine, and the name does not ring a bell, either, even though that may be a transcription thing? Part of Poland was under Austro-Hungarian rule in the 19th century so we do share some dishes, like goulash.
@Linda Jo Good point! LOVE, LET, DEUCE and so on. (Incidentally, this puzzle has really riled those solvers who LOVE LET-DEUCE vs. kale in their Caesar salads.)

EMUs?

HUGE SPOILERS - read on at own peril if spoilers are not what you seek.


Out of the US holiday flavors, you would taste only gingerbread in Poland at Christmas time (in fact, my wife baked wonderful gingerbread cookies last week and our place still smells of them wonderfully). None of the other stuff features in our seasonal dishes. In fact, cranberry only arrived in Poland with market economy in the past three decades - it was largely unknown before, as it does not grow here and import really was not a thing pre-1989. Us Poles like to eat our meats with berry condiment, but our go-to for centuries was lingonberry, which is native to our climate.

We like our cocoa, but it is not a Christmas flavor, specifically.

Peppermint, and mint in general, is not popular in cooking here. The only traditional Polish use for mint was as a herbal infusion said to alleviate symptoms of indigestion.

We feast on Christmas eve, not Christmas day. For some religious reason (don't ask me, the atheist, for the details), meat and meat products are traditionally banned. Traditional Xmas eve dishes include fried carp, borscht ("barszcz" in Polish), mushroom-cabbage pierogi ("pierogi z kapustƒÖ i grzybami"), poppyseed desserts (of various kinds depending on the region of Poland), and meat-free bigos (a sort of stew of saurkraut and mushrooms). Meat is back on the menu for breakfast on Christmas morning - a carved home-made roast might feature then.

My non-traditional family ate other stuff though.

@Andrzej 

Thank you!  As always very informative.  

Regarding the peppermint, I believe it is included in today's set due to the use of peppermint candy canes that are used to adorn the Christmas Tree (a long with all the other decorations).  I'm sure I liked them as a kid but have no use for them now. 

Our local volunteer fire companies do a tour through the neighborhood, with a volunteer dressed as Santa, and they give out peppermint candy canes.  

And since I now live in NJ I have to give a shout out to the noble Cranberry which are grown in large, drainable ponds.  The water is for pest control and then in harvesting.

I have to confess, I love love love all the seasonal treats that get faint praise from most people I know: eggnog, fruitcake, peppermint... I've always chalked it up to being a Christmas baby: must come with the territory somehow! 

I'd count gingerbread as another Christmas classic, of course. But cranberries, like turkey, belong to the previous holiday, IMHO. 

This was a fun puzzle! Very happy to have found the spangram first: I don't think I've seen a configuration like that before. Nice long words, and that low wordcount!

@Andrzej 

That food sounds delicious. I've always said I should have been born in eastern Europe, taste-wise. 

I only know lingonberries from IKEA, but they have a similar tart flavor profile to cranberries, and are from the same berry family along with blueberries and huckleberries (and others). The tartness works well with fatty or gamey meats.  

The main difference seems to be that lingonberries have some sweetness, while cranberries have almost none.  Tricking young family members into eating raw cranberries used to be a fun thanksgiving activity many years ago.  They are just pure tartness with no sugar added.

@G 

I have to chime in in favor of fruitcake. I don't know why it gets its bad rap. I love it - all kinds, the typical American style, stollen, panettone, black cake, it's all delicious.

@Grant - When I was a grad student in Orono, one of the university cow pastures was right behind my building, which was right on the main campus. 

It was converted to a parking lot about 40 years ago. 

UMO (sometimes called UM0 (that's a zero) by local wags) still owns and operates research farms, including some not far from campus. They had the oldest organic agriculture research farm in the country, which has more recently been re-oriented to sustainable agriculture. It is the oldest program in sustainable agriculture in the country. 

The ag students in dairy used to make and sell the best ice cream, which could be purchased on campus. I have no idea if they still do that -- something to check out when the weather warms.

@CaptainQuahog 
I grew up in Storrs, CT where UCONN is, and they too had a big agricultural program and lots of cow barns when I was living there. We used to toboggan down ‚Äúhorse barn hill.‚Äù Also, an ag student run dairy bar like you describe where we routinely went for ice cream as kids. Sam‚Äôs comment about never having heard of ORONO kinda surprised me, as it has appeared about 250 times clued to that school. But, I see that it has not appeared on a M-W since she started  writing the column. Lots of good vowels. Interestingly, none of the other New England State University towns have regularly appeared. AMHERST has appeared over 30 times, but never clued specifically to UMASS. DURHAM was clued once to UNH in 1959. STORRS was an answer  just twice, in 1951 and 1967. Go Back Bears!

@CaptainQuahog - One of my favorite students did her undergrad research on damming and undamming rivers up Maine way; she got her graduate degrees at U Maine Orono and has devoted her life to undoing human damage - dammage - damnage - on the great rivers of Maine.

@Steve L I think for us Canadians it‚Äôs a bad clue because of a few reasons. ‚ÄúOntario-based‚Äù either misdirects to presume something innately Ontarian about the CBC or that there is something relevant about its headquarters being here. More than this, conservative politicians regularly threaten to defund CBC as a gesture against federalism, our current Liberal government, and really mainstream media in general. So there is some politics around the CBC as our national broadcaster that‚Äôs tied into larger narratives around national identity (and our simultaneous inferiority complex/exceptionalist snobbishness toward the US) that make the Ontario-specific reference a bit complicated for us!

 But we do love it when America pays attention to us.

@Steve L  The clue is ‚Äúbased in‚Äù not ‚Äúheadquartered in‚Äù, which is not really the same thing. In the Canadian federal context it should be regarded as drastically different. I worked in CBC for decades and it would have been a heresy to claim that the corporation was ‚Äúbased in Ontario.‚Äù

@Kevin Elliott 

Maybe that‚Äôs the problem. I don‚Äôt see any difference between being based and being headquartered in a place. I don‚Äôt see either as limiting how far a company‚Äôs reach is. If you substitute based into my example sentences, I don‚Äôt find that it changes anything.

Steve L,

I‚Äôm with you. 
It was a crossword clue, not a comment on public broadcasting or Canadian national identity. 
For Schitt‚Äôs Creek people - relax!

@Steve L it's just one of those things that sounds weird to folks inside the culture. The CBC is the national broadcaster. I have never once heard it referred to as being in any way based in Ontario regardless of whether that is technically true. It's just not how we think about our talk about the CBC. So while it is probably fine as a crossword clue in an American newspaper, it fails the shibboleth test.

@Steve L

I didn‚Äôt notice this while solving ( I had the initial C), but I kinda see the point made by the Canada based commentators.

Would it be considered OK to clue NPR as a ‚Äúa DC based media company‚Äù? 

The clue is technically correct IMO, but just a bit off - Especially on a Monday?

@RampiAK 

I think it would be 100% OK beyond the shadow of a doubt to clue NPR as a DC-based media company.  Everyone and everything has to come from somewhere.

I think we might have stumbled upon a certain quirk of the Canadian psyche that went unnoticed before.  The whole country thinks of the CBC as theirs, and so they find it off that we refer to it by where it is based, which factually is Ontario, apparently.

I also realize that as a non-Canadian looking in from the outside, I may not get fully what they're feeling because this is a peculiarity.  There's no other way to put it.  No matter what I said in my original, reasoned-out comment, it's going to seem "off" to many Canadians.

And so we must fall back on the notion that the NYT reflects how the main constituency, Americans, would react to the clue.

@Sarah 
ORONO is more the kind of thing you‚Äôd see in other crosswords. ST ELMO has become very popular in the past few years in NYT crosswords, and many others.  Both answers give you a ‚Äúgimme‚Äù in the more challenging puzzles, for what it‚Äôs worth.
